newsitem.title: USA: Former GATT head hopes Cuba row settled out of WTO.
newsitem.headline: Former GATT head hopes Cuba row settled out of WTO.

text.p: The former head of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade said Friday he hopes a dispute over whether a U.S. anti-Cuba law violates World Trade Organization rules is settled outside WTO processes.

Peter Sutherland, who was designated chairman of the Overseas Development Council Thursday, said fallout from the dispute over the U.S. Helms-Burton law has the potential to shake confidence in the WTO and its ability to resolve major trade disputes.
"I'm just simply saying that it's dangerous," Sutherland said in response to a question after speaking to a group of journalists at the National Press Club.
Rather than threaten the WTO's dispute-resolution mechanisms, Sutherland said he hopes the dispute is resolved by agreement of the parties, outside the auspices of the WTO.

Sutherland, a general partner of Goldman Sachs and chairman and managing director of Goldman Sachs International, was the director-general of GATT, which preceded the WTO. The OCD is a Washington-based research group that studies trade and multilateral institutions.
The WTO agreed to a European Union request in November to set up a panel to decide whether the U.S. law violates its rules.
The law, which punishes foreigners who invest in properties confiscated from Americans in Cuba, has been criticized by an overwhelming number of U.S. trading partners.

U.S. officials have said that the anti-Cuba law falls under an untested "national security" clause of the two-year-old, 125-member WTO, under which countries can override WTO rules if they see their security at stake.
